Post Description:
Like many of you, I have been concerned about how vulnerable segments of our society have coped during the circuit breaker. While the measures are necessary to keep everyone safe, it has posed additional challenges for the more vulnerable, including those with special needs.‚Å£
‚Å£

Like many of us, Catherine has been working from home during this time. She has been attending online courses to improve her customer service skills and working on The Art Faculty‚Äôs online store (www.theartfaculty.sg). ‚Å£
‚Å£
As we come to the end of the circuit breaker, I would like to thank SG Enable and our Social Service Agency partners for taking care of those with special needs and the vulnerable in our community. Even as we look forward to the end of our circuit breaker, let us continue to look out for one another and strengthen our collective actions to build a caring and inclusive society for all.‚Å£

Post Description:
I was very happy to e-meet many familiar faces from the social service sector on Saturday, together with @desmond.lee, @gracefu.hy and @indraneerajah, ahead of my Ministerial Statement next Tuesday.

We heard from 30 social service sector partners, on the challenges they and their clients are facing. We discussed how our social service agencies can strengthen collaboration and capability building. Their passion to serve came through during the dialogue, as they are doing all they can to strengthen support for vulnerable members of our community during the circuit breaker. The circuit breaker has accelerated the shift to digital, as more services are provided online. This highlighted both the potential and also the current constraints of going digital. Many also shared their concerns about the difficulties with fundraising during this period.

Many good ideas were raised. I will look at how we can better support the social service sector as part of the upcoming Budget. We will also work with the sector to embrace digitalisation, accelerate transformation and scale up new capabilities.

What is even more heartening is how the sector is working together. Some participants were already working closely together, and new areas of collaboration were identified during our discussions. The sector faces many common challenges, but we can overcome them if we work in partnership, and put our collective effort into tackling them. This is the spirit of our #SingaporeTogether movement.

We are making good progress towards building a more caring and inclusive society. We will build an even better tomorrow, with the strong support of social service agencies.

Post Description:
We will be exiting the circuit breaker when it ends on 1 June. The number of new community cases is in the low single-digits, and our surveillance shows that the number of undetected cases in the community is small. While there are new cases in our migrant worker dormitories, the situation has stabilised.‚Å£
‚Å£
We are preparing to re-open some of our economic and social activities. But learning from the experience of other countries, this has to be done cautiously and gradually. If we re-open too quickly, we risk new waves of infection, which could be even more disruptive to lives and livelihoods. As announced by the Multi-Ministry Taskforce, we will be resuming social and economic activities in phases, with additional safeguards in place.‚Å£
‚Å£
I understand the disappointment of some businesses and workers who will not be able to resume activities immediately when the circuit breaker ends. For these workers and businesses, the Government will help tide you over this period of continued closure. I will announce the details in Parliament next Tuesday, 26 May.‚Å£
‚Å£
Medical experts have cautioned that this smart and agile virus will continue to be in our midst and in global circulation for some time to come. This is why all of us in Singapore and in the global community must not let our guard down. Some of the safe distancing measures will be here to stay. COVID-19 is changing our way of life and livelihoods. We must recognise that it is important for all of us to adjust our lifestyles and adapt our business models.‚Å£
‚Å£
I thank everyone in Singapore for your understanding and cooperation, as well as for your mutual care and concern for one other during this circuit breaker. Let‚Äôs continue to stay vigilant and civic-minded in the months ahead.‚Å£
‚Å£
#SGUnited

Post Description:
Today is the last day of full Home-Based Learning (HBL). The past four weeks have been challenging for everyone involved.

For Teachers, this means putting in extra time and effort to prepare. HBL is a different mode of teaching, and you have to be creative and learn new skills to make online learning as engaging as possible.

For Parents, you have to support your children in the best possible way, even as you juggle working from home and housework.

For Students, I know many of you miss your classmates, your favourite hangouts and CCAs in schools. E-learning is not new, but having to do so remotely for a month is a completely different way to learn.

Challenging as it is for everyone, this experience also creates many memorable stories. I urge you all to share these, so that we can all learn about what worked, what did not; why not, and how we can do better.

Let us all be prepared to try new things, adapt and grow with this new experience, and we may just become more innovative after this! The first step in any innovation is to overcome the fear of the unknown. But if the new approach is better, we can learn better. If the traditional approach is better, we will appreciate it more, and look forward to going back to school!

Education Minister @ongyekung has brought forward our mid-year school holidays, so that everyone can have a respite. I strongly encourage all parents and students to explore new activities to spend quality time together, at home. I hope all our teachers who have been working very hard can also take a well-deserved break, before some of you have to help graduating cohorts prepare for their national exams from 19 May.

The second half of the circuit breaker is just as crucial. Stay strong and stay safe, as we #StayhomeforSG.

#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether
Comments: Thanks to the teachers and school for continuing the students learning at home during the pandemic. They put in lots of efforts and passion in their works.

The months of April and May will be a test of our resilience, as individuals and as a society.

‚†Ä
This is why PM @leehsienloong has just announced a further tightening of measures for two weeks, and an extension of the circuit breaker by four weeks, until 1 Jun.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

‚†Ä

‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ I will extend the 75% wage subsidy under the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) to all sectors for the month of May. I urge employers to treat their workers fairly, and to do their best to retain them, and make full use of the support measures for training and corporate upgrading.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ I will further enhance the JSS to include shareholder-directors who did not qualify for JSS, based on the earlier criteria, and also did not qualify for SIRS.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ I will also be waiving the Foreign Worker Levy (FWL) due in May and provide employers with another $750 in FWL rebate for every foreign worker in employment.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

‚†Ä

Comments: I pray for the well being of our seniors. They have given so much to Singapore

Post Description:
#StayhomeforSG challenge was launched yesterday to encourage Singaporeans to stay active and engaged, even as we stay home. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Like many of us, I am concerned about how our seniors are coping, that they may feel lonely or isolated. Our elderly are most vulnerable to COVID-19. With the circuit breaker in place, they should stay home as much as possible. We can visit to assist them with their daily needs while keeping the visits short. This is the best way to protect their well-being. It is not easy to explain that we may sometimes have to stay away because we care, but we must do so.

We can still show care and concern for the elderly, even when we are not physically present. There are many ways to keep in touch ‚Äî through WhatsApp, video-conferencing apps such as Skype, or just a simple phone call.

We also have much more content on TV during this period. For those who are interested in getai, you can also tune into e-getais every Monday and Thursday on Lex S Watch Live Channel's FB page. This is a @gov.sg collaboration with producer @jackneock for our seniors to enjoy the familiar tunes from yesterdays in the comfort of our homes.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Let us all help our elderly family members adapt so that they can remain happy and engaged at home. Safe distancing does not mean social isolation.‚†Ä ‚†Ä
I encourage those with good ideas on how to keep our seniors engaged at home to come forward and take part in the #StayhomeforSG challenge.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Together, we can get through this difficult period.‚†Ä

‚†Ä

Let us all help our elderly family members adapt so that they can remain happy and engaged at home. Safe distancing does not mean social isolation.‚†Ä ‚†Ä
I encourage those with good ideas on how to keep our seniors engaged at home to come forward and take part in the #StayhomeforSG challenge.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Together, we can get through this difficult period.‚†Ä

Post Description:
We are living in extraordinary times.

This is the first time in our history that we will be closing all schools and most workplaces across the island for a month ‚Äî a painful but necessary ‚Äòcircuit breaker‚Äô to stem the tide of COVID-19 cases.

Tomorrow afternoon, when Parliament sits, I will announce additional support for workers, businesses and households, to help tide them through this period.

The COVID-19 situation has taken a very sharp turn, both globally and locally. Strong measures have to be taken to protect lives, but the economy has taken a hit as a result. Tomorrow will mark the third round of support measures in less than two months ‚Äî coming after the Unity Budget on 18 Feb and the Resilience Budget on 26 March. This too is another first.

We must remain steadfast in the face of crisis, and stand in solidarity with one another during these difficult times. I am therefore naming this set of measures to tide us through the 'circuit breaker' the Solidarity Budget.

Unity, Resilience, Solidarity ‚Äî these values will come to define who we are as a people. The bonds that bind us together will be forged and renewed in this crisis, much as how the turbulent years of Independence brought our founding generation together. As we battle on, we are most grateful that earlier generations have saved up and built strong foundations for us. These strengths have given us the wherewithal to protect our people and their jobs.

This is a defining chapter of our generation. Together, we will pull through and emerge stronger. When the storm eventually subsides, as all storms do, I am confident that as a stronger society, we can build an even better future for our children and our grandchildren.

#SGUnited (MCI Photo by Clement)

Post Description:
PM @leehsienloong announced yesterday a set of significantly stricter measures, as a circuit breaker to curb the escalating number of new COVID-19 cases. Most workplaces, except for essential services and key economic sectors, will close for one month from next Tuesday.

We are implementing these painful but necessary measures to protect lives. The stronger the measures we adopt, the bigger the disruption and costs on businesses. We remain equally committed to protecting jobs and livelihoods during this time. Many businesses are looking at your cash flow and working out alternative arrangements over the weekend. I understand your worries.

That is why I am working with my team at the @mof_sg, together with other government agencies, to further increase support for businesses during the period of the circuit breaker. This includes boosting the Job Support Scheme and waiving the foreign worker levy for the month of April, so that companies can retain and pay their workers. We will also be passing legislation on Tuesday (7 April) in Parliament to ensure that property tax rebates are passed through to tenants.

This is undoubtedly a difficult month for many businesses. Additional help is on the way. I hope that businesses can tide through this month, hold on to your workers, and resume activities once the circuit breaker is lifted. Together, we can pull through this crisis.

I will announce the details in my ministerial statement in Parliament on Monday.

#SGUnited (Taken during my recent visit to Changi Airport Terminal 3 on 30 March 2020./ MCI Photo by LH Goh)
Comments: Thanks for time and effort done by you and your team Mr DPM, do take care and rest well.

We remain equally committed to protecting jobs and livelihoods during this time. Many businesses are looking at your cash flow and working out alternative arrangements over the weekend. I understand your worries.

That is why I am working with my team at the @mof_sg, together with other government agencies, to further increase support for businesses during the period of the circuit breaker. This includes boosting the Job Support Scheme and waiving the foreign worker levy for the month of April, so that companies can retain and pay their workers. We will also be passing legislation on Tuesday (7 April) in Parliament to ensure that property tax rebates are passed through to tenants.

This is undoubtedly a difficult month for many businesses. Additional help is on the way. I hope that businesses can tide through this month, hold on to your workers, and resume activities once the circuit breaker is lifted. Together, we can pull through this crisis.

I will announce the details in my ministerial statement in Parliament on Monday.

Last Friday, we announced the closure of all mosques in Singapore for five days, to facilitate cleaning and disinfection procedures so as to prevent the emergence of new clusters. This move came after two Singaporeans who attended a religious gathering in Malaysia had returned here with COVID-19. As of today, a total of five Singaporeans who attended the event have now tested positive for the virus. They had visited 10 mosques in Singapore during their infectious period. Today, @masagosz announced that the mosque closure will be extended till 26 March 2020 to further limit the spread of the virus.

I understand that the closure of mosques and suspension of Friday prayers will cause inconvenience to our friends from the Muslim community.
